pros: Supportive team, trainings, lots of clients

pros: Good staff, everyone is very friendly and very professional Good benefits Good health insurance Good work environment
cons: The merge with MultiCare, so much confusion.
Multicare restructuring has changed company culture

review_title: 0/10, would not recommend to anyone as employer
job_title: Adult Outpatient Therapist in Lakewood, WA
pros: You will get hours needed toward licensure. You will experience working with any and everyone on a wide variety of issues. You will get experience in managing crises. You will get experience in case management and social work needs. You will get experience in calling APS and CPS with or against client wishes. You will receive group and individual supervision.
cons: Most therapists do not have regular access to an office. You must check out an office at the beginning of session, but not before they have checked in. You may not stay in an office you have used for your previous client, unless your next client has already checked in. Someone will open the door without knocking while you are mid session, most likely several times, while you work there. You will not receive adequate training or support to address high intensity, important, needs (housing, food, substance withdrawal, financial support, childcare). Your clients may be verbally or physically assaulted while waiting for an appointment. You will be verbally or physically threatened or assaulted multiple times by clients; sometimes yours, sometimes not. You will be approached for money by our clients while walking in, out, or around the building as they are unable to get their needs met by the providers inside. You will be expected to participate in extrovert events, with appreciate and gratitude, regardless of your own needs. There is an expectation of martyrdom to do this work without appropriate compensation, with working into personal time, and completing paperwork requirements to 95% perfection, and gaslighting about these not being the expectations because legally they cannot endorse the work culture they expect. It’s been almost five years since I left and I still have nightmares at least once a month. Sometimes about not being able to find a client or get a room for them, other times about being exhausted and ill from work there, gaslit about needs not being met, and honestly a lot of dreams about being hungry or needing to use the bathroom and not being able to even do that.

pros: A lot of autonomy working in schools
cons: Have to learn epic system Very old work phone (think off brand flip phone)

pros: Experienced senior management. Dedicated small teams that are passionate about helping the community. High level counselors that provides therapeutic recovery approach. Great quality care for consumers.
cons:
GLMHC is technically a non-profit organization but a closer look would identify it differently. Optum is the RSN for GLMHC and they are for a for-profit company with shareholders and agendas. Optum will push their agenda and threaten to pull funding away from GLMHC if Optum doesn’t get their way. 
GLMHC equipment is outdated. Computers are an Intel single physical core processor without any video cards or drivers. The software GLMHC uses for everything is called PSYCH-CONSULT, which GLMHC has only purchased a limited amount of licenses – which often leaves the employee unable to finish their work if the rest of the building is using that program. 
The turnover levels for CM2’s is high. CM2 client load varies from 45-65 individuals with a needed productivity of 85%. 
Long story short. GLMHC used to have that small non-profit feel. There are no bonuses or incentives to excel at GLMHC. As a residential counselor, CM2 or CM3 expect to get left-overs in the cafeteria from parties that senior level managers have. Expect a starting pay of 14 dollars an hour with your Masters degree. Expect your computer not to function. Expect to have regular meetings with your supervisor for not meeting productivity (100% of employees goes through it, not just the bottom 30%). Expect problematic circumstances when requesting for PTO. Expect Optum healthcare (GLMHC funding source) to get your hard earned bonuses, shutting down office and taking holiday vacations while you're at work. Expect not to be impressed from the larger scope of the company.

pros:
Greater Lakes is a great place to make a significant impact in the mental health care field. There is a diverse range of clients and greater lakes offers a ton of support to clinicians. 

I had met wonderful people in the GL team and believe there is plenty of opportunity for growth at GL.
cons: While Greater Lakes offers support to its staff, there seems to be a disconnect with understanding the demands of a clinician. During my time at Greater Lakes, productivity was very important (as in almost all community mental health agencies) but seemed to be the focus of management not necessarily the quality of care provided.

review_title: This job is a stepping stone

quarterly bonuses when exceeding productivity
depending on the location you will have your own office

inconsistent protocols
they care more about the numbers than the clients'
60+ caseloads
pay does not warrant the amount of work that comes with the job. severely underpaid

pros: I like working here because the staff really seem to work together. There is a team-approach and decisions are made with a lot of staff input. It feels like a relaxed, fun place to work where there is no undercurrent of high-stress
cons: It is a large organization, and sometimes feels like decisions and changes are slow to come about because of all the layers of bereaucracy.  But less so than other large places I've worked. The work can be emotionally difficult.

pros: Great co-workers, some supportive managers, ability to work flexible hours.
cons: productivity, pay, micromanagement, long hours, big caseloads,lack of support

review_title: Great management, too much stress for the pay
pros: Managers and coworkers are phenomenal. Clinical experience gained on the job is definitely a pro. If you can manage to keep up with the paperwork, then you’ll learn to be a well organized person.
cons: For the amount of stress on the job, the pay is just too little. Caseloads are too high as well

review_title: Quick, Responsive, and easy to follow HR process
pros: GLMHC has been easy to follow and supportive throughout the hiring and on boarding process.
cons: To date GLMHC is supportive. When I clock out, no one calls and no other work is expected.

pros: Not micro managed, freedom as long as you do your job well.
cons: Pay is not great, but can negotiate  your pay depending on your experience.

review_title: Has Workplace Bullying Atmosphere In Peer Counseling Department
pros: There are not really any pros to think of, except for decent health benefits to its workers.
cons: There's a current climate of workplace bullying by Peer Counseling Managerial staff. This causes undue stress on Peer Counselors and causes a high turnover as a result.

pros: Leadership is completely transparent with staff about what is going on in the company.
